Dear Ms. Ahart
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/9/2023. An exit conference was held with you on 8/9/2023 with follow up information
on 8/10/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at .
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One of four new employee records reviewed did not
show documentation of any references for the employee.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a
written evaluation of the convictions that addresses the
nature of the conviction, the length of time since the
conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to
regulated activity.
2

One of four new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of a chief
administrator or designee written evaluation of a 2019 disorderly person's conviction
for the employee.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2): The personnel record must contain all of the
following information before employment may occur:
(g) A written statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
One of four new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of a
written statement from the employee related to a 2019 disorderly person’s
conviction.
FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may also
include extended family, friends, neighbors, community-
based service providers, community representatives,
tribal representatives, for Indian children, or other
professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table.
• Case Plan Development/ Reassessment.
In one of three updated service plans (USP) reviewed (related to one of three youth
records), the record did not show documentation of an FTM for the youth's
2/18/2023-5/18/2023 USP. One was completed far too soon on 3/6/2023.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
FOM 722-8D Treatment plan.
Agreement and Signature:
3

Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
One of three updated service plans reviewed did not show documentation of the
youth's signature on the treatment plan.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12509(3(o) Independent living record
• The agency was apprised its 30-day report shall consistently and clearly
document the reason for the case responsibility change, as required by
R400.12418(3), and be signed and dated by worker and supervisor.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Nothing this inspection.
EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this
licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2022 Renewal
inspection where the agency received the following rule and policy violations:
• R400.12509 (3) Independent living record.
• R400.12511(1)(c) &(d) Termination (incorrectly listed in the Renewal
report as, Independent living contract).
• R400.12511(2)(a)-(d) Termination (incorrectly listed in the Renewal
report as, Independent living contract).
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
4

The agency made progress on this corrective action plan. It provided
documentation showing proofs of the indicated trainings and implementation of
various items reported in the corrective action plan.
Notwithstanding the progress the agency made on this corrective plan, the agency
received one repeat violation as indicated in this inspection report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted an annual chief administrator's report date 8/9/2023. It was
completed as required. No concerns were noted.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual budget, and 2022 completed financial audit
dated 5/22/2023. No areas of concern were observed from these financial
documents.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to contact with the chief administrator, and program manager, one
independent living case worker and two independent living youth advocates were
interviewed. No concerns were noted.
Two youths were interviews. No significant concerns were reported by the youths.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk though of the agency's office and independent living housing unit were
completed. No safety issues or concerns were observed.
VI. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
This is not applicable. This agency only provided independent living services.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
